column4: if its not installed try "sudo apt-get install build-essential
to check what version you have you can type "gcc -v"

Thanks. I sudo apt-get install gcc. Do I need to get build-essential too?

depends. i usually just install build-essential because i'll wind up needing it eventually.  You'll need it if you ever install something from source, but if your just trying to compile your c program installing gcc should be enough.
I'm trying to compile c++.
g++ is for compiling c++
!build-essential
So should I sudo apt-get g++?
you probably already have it but you can type "sudo apt-get install g++" and it will install it if you don't have it

Thanks. I'm asking all this because I tryed to compile a program using the command g++ and it said no such command was found. I took your advice and installed build essential which solved my problem. Thanks a bunch. You guys are great!
no problem :) its always great when we can help people
One last thing. If I have a executable, how do I make it so I can just type the name in the terminal and the program is executed?
That is without having to navigate to the folder
you would have to add the directory the file is in to your path.  For now though I think it would just be easier to type ./filename to run it.
or if its in a different directory you would type ./directorytofile/filename
